questions.question_text: At the end of initiation there is +1 week 1-2 weeks time tolerance for this project. Which statement is true?

choices.D: Additional time tolerance for the project could be found by adding extra resources without affecting other tolerances.
choices.C: The Stage Plan for stage 2 could create some additional project time tolerance by allowing no time tolerance in Team Plans.
choices.B: All of the project level time tolerance can be allocated to stage 2.
choices.A: There can be no time tolerances for any of the stages.

discussion.content: If stage 2 is last stage then option B is true otherwise option C

C. The Stage Plan for stage 2 could create some additional project time tolerance by allowing no time tolerance in Team Plans.

This is because the project time tolerance of +1 week / -2 weeks is a buffer for the entire project, not just for one stage. If the Stage Plan for stage 2 does not use any of this tolerance (i.e., it is planned to be completed on time), then the remaining project time tolerance could be used for other stages or unforeseen delays. This would effectively create additional project time tolerance.

comments.content: In init stage you can use all of your tolerances.

During stage 2, if the Project Manager decides to recommend that the Project Plan is revised to finish three weeks later, which statement is correct?
A. The tolerances stated in the Project Plan CANNOT be changed.
B. The Executive needs to seek formal approval from corporate management to implement this change.
C. The current project must close prematurely and be restarted with a new Project Plan, a new Business Case and new Risk Register.
D. The revision of the Project Plan would have to wait until the end stage assessment of stage 2.

comments.content:
B. The Executive needs to seek formal approval from corporate management to implement this change.

This is because a change in the Project Plan, especially one that affects the project’s timeline, is a significant event. It can impact resources, costs, and deliverables. Therefore, such a change typically requires approval from higher management or stakeholders to ensure alignment with organizational goals and strategies.
